title: Which was the best Roman legion in history and why? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a hard question because of the definition of best : was it the most successful one ? the one that lasted the longest ? the one with the most trusted and competent officer ? the bravest one in battle ? We certainly know of bad commanders and hence “bad” legions : number XVII to XIX were completely destroyed in the Teutoburg Forest and their numbers were never used again after that. Even the names of those legions were erased from records and forgotten. Here are my favorite five worthy Roman Legions : 1 - Legio II Augusta Active : 43 BC to sometime in the 4th century ADNickname(s) : Augusta, "Augustan" under AugustusAntonina, "Antoninian" under Caracalla or ElagabalusMascot : Capricornus, in its sea-goat form the astrological sign of II Augusta's patron, AugustusEngagements : Philippi (42 BC), Perugia (41 BC-40 BC), Cantabrian Wars (25 BC-19 BC), Invasion of Britain (43-66), Severus Scottish campaign (208)Notable commanders : Vespasian, Septimius Severus, Tiberius Claudius Paulinus2 - Legio VI Ferrata Active : 65 BC to at least 215 ADNickname(s) : Fidelis Constans ("loyal and steadfast")Mascot : She-wolf with Romulus and Remus, BullEngagements : Battle of Pharsalus (48 BC), Siege of Alexandria (47 BC), Battle of Zela (47 BC), Battle of Munda (45 BC)…Notable commanders : Julius Caesar, Mark Antony, Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo3 - Legio VII Claudia Active : 59 BC to sometime in the 5th centuryNickname(s) : Pia VI Fidelis VI ("six times devoted and faithful”)Paterna ("fatherly")Macedonica ("macedonian")Antonina ("faithful to Antoninus")Pia Severiana ("faithful to Severus")Severiana Alexandriana ("faithful to Alexander Severus")Pia VII Fidelis VII ("seven times devoted and faithful”)Mascot : BullEngagements : Gallic Wars (58–51 BC), Battle of Alesia (52 BC), Caesar's Civil War (49–45 BC), Battle of Pharsalus (48 BC), Battle of Thapsus (46 BC), Parthian campaigns of Trajan and Lucius Verus, Marcomannic Wars (166–180 AD)…Notable commanders : Julius Caesar, Mark Antony, Augustus, Trajan, Lucius Verus, Marcus Aurelius4 - Legio VIII Augusta Active : 59 BC to sometime in the 5th centuryMascot : BullEngagements : Gallic Wars (58–51 BC), Battle against the Nervians (57 BC), Battle of Gergovia (52 BC), Battle of Alesia (52 BC), Battle of Thapsus (46 BC), Invasion of Britain (43-66)Notable commanders : Julius Caesar, Augustus5 - Legio XIII Gemina Active : 57 BC to sometime in the 5th centuryNickname(s) : Gemina, "The twin" (since 31 BC) / Pia Fidelis, "Faithful and loyal"Mascot : LionEngagements : Gallic Wars (58–51 BC), Battle against the Nervians (57 BC), Battle of Gergovia (52 BC), Battle of Alesia (52 BC), Battle of Dyrrhachium (48 BC), Battle of Pharsalus (48 BC), Battle of Thapsus (46 BC), Battle of Munda (45 BC), Battle of Actium (31 BC), 1st and 2nd Battle of Bedriacum (69), Dacian Wars (101–102,105–106)…Notable commanders : Julius Caesar, Marcus Salvius Otho, Marcus Antonius Primus

Legio X Gemina was clearly among those favored by Julius Caesar. The Tenth was the first legion levied personally by Caesar when in Hispania and was consistently his most trusted. It was one of the four legions used by Caesar in 58 BC, for his invasion of Gaul. There are still records of the X Gemina in Vienna in the beginning of the 5th century. Early on in its history, the legion was called legio X Equestris (mounted), because Caesar once used the its members as make-shift cavalry. In Gaul, Legio X played an important role on Caesar's military success and for this reason is sometimes said to be his favorite. In Caesar's campaigns they were present in the battle of the Sabis, the invasions of Britain, and the battle of Gergovia. They remained faithful to Caesar in the civil war against Pompey, being present in the battles of Pharsalus (49 BC) and Munda (45 BC). In 45 BC, Caesar disbanded the legion, rewarding the veterans with farmlands near Narbonne in Gaul and in Hispania. Its remnants were reconstituted, fought for Mark Antony and Octavian, disbanded, and later merged into Legio X Gemina.
